The **Supreme Court of the United States** is the
[highest](/wiki/Supreme_court "Supreme court") [federal court of the United
States](/wiki/Federal_judiciary_of_the_United_States "Federal judiciary of the
United States"). Established pursuant to [Article Three of the United States
Constitution](/wiki/Article_Three_of_the_United_States_Constitution "Article
Three of the United States Constitution") in 1789, it has ultimate (and
largely
[discretionary](/wiki/Procedures_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States
"Procedures of the Supreme Court of the United States")) [appellate
jurisdiction](/wiki/Appellate_jurisdiction "Appellate jurisdiction") over all
federal courts and [state court](/wiki/State_court_\(United_States\) "State
court \(United States\)") cases involving issues of [federal
law](/wiki/U.S._federal_law "U.S. federal law") plus [original
jurisdiction](/wiki/Original_jurisdiction "Original jurisdiction") over a
small range of cases. In the [legal system of the United
States](/wiki/Law_of_the_United_States "Law of the United States"), the
Supreme Court is generally the final interpreter of [federal
law](/wiki/Law_of_the_United_States "Law of the United States") including the
[United States Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States
Constitution"), but it may act only within the context of a case, in which it
has jurisdiction. The Court may decide cases having political overtones but
does not have power to decide [nonjusticiable](/wiki/Justiciability
"Justiciability") [political questions](/wiki/Political_question "Political
question"), and [its enforcement arm](/wiki/United_States_Marshals_Service
"United States Marshals Service") is in the executive rather than judicial
branch of government.

According to federal statute, the Court normally consists of the [Chief
Justice of the United States](/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_United_States "Chief
Justice of the United States") and eight [associate
justices](/wiki/Associate_Justice_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States
"Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States") who are
nominated by the [President](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President
of the United States") and confirmed by the
[Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate"). Once appointed,
justices have [lifetime tenure](/wiki/Life_tenure "Life tenure") unless they
resign, retire, or are removed after
[impeachment](/wiki/Impeachment_in_the_United_States "Impeachment in the
United States") (though no justice has ever been removed).[2] In modern
discourse, the justices are often categorized as having
[conservative](/wiki/Conservatism_in_the_United_States#Courts "Conservatism in
the United States"), [moderate](/wiki/Moderate "Moderate"), or
[liberal](/wiki/Liberalism_in_the_United_States#Courts "Liberalism in the
United States") [philosophies of law](/wiki/Philosophy_of_law "Philosophy of
law") and of [judicial interpretation](/wiki/Judicial_interpretation "Judicial
interpretation"). Each justice has one vote, and it is worth noting that while
a far greater number of cases in recent history have been decided unanimously,
decisions in cases of the highest profile have often come down to just one
single vote, thereby exposing the justices' ideological beliefs that track
with those philosophical or political categories. The Court meets in the
[Supreme Court Building](/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court_Building "United
States Supreme Court Building") in [Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C.
"Washington, D.C.")

The Supreme Court is sometimes colloquially referred to as _SCOTUS_ (_**S**_
upreme _**C**_ ourt _**o**_ f _**t**_ he _**U**_ nited _**S**_ tates) similar
to and in line with other [acronyms](/wiki/Acronyms "Acronyms") such as
_[POTUS](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United
States")_ (_**P**_ resident _**o**_ f _**t**_ he _**U**_ nited _**S**_
tates).[3]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

Main article: [History of the Supreme Court of the United
States](/wiki/History_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "History of
the Supreme Court of the United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Oblique_facade_2%2C_US_Supreme_Court.jpg/260px-
Oblique_facade_2%2C_US_Supreme_Court.jpg)](/wiki/File:Oblique_facade_2,_US_Supreme_Court.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Oblique_facade_2,_US_Supreme_Court.jpg "Enlarge")

Supreme Court of the United States

The ratification of the [United States
Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States Constitution")
established the Supreme Court in 1789. Its powers are detailed in [Article
Three of the
Constitution](/wiki/Article_Three_of_the_United_States_Constitution "Article
Three of the United States Constitution"). The Supreme Court was the only
court specifically established by the Constitution while all other federal
courts were created by [Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States
Congress"). Congress is also responsible for conferring the title of "justice"
to its members, who are known to scold lawyers for inaccurately referring to
them as "judge", even though it is the term used in the Constitution.[4]

The Court first convened on February 2, 1790[5] with six judges where only
five of its six initial positions were filled. According to historian Fergus
Bordewich, in its first session: "[T]he Supreme Court convened for the first
time at the [Royal Exchange Building](/wiki/Royal_Exchange,_New_York "Royal
Exchange, New York") on Broad Street, a few steps from Federal Hall.
Symbolically, the moment was pregnant with promise for the republic, this
birth of a new national institution whose future power, admittedly, still
existed only in the eyes and minds of just a few visionary Americans.
Impressively bewigged and swathed in their robes of office, Chief Justice John
Jay and three associate justices — William Cushing of Massachusetts, James
Wilson of Pennsylvania, and John Blair of Virginia — sat augustly before a
throng of spectators and waited for something to happen. Nothing did. They had
no cases to consider. After a week of inactivity, they adjourned until
September, and everyone went home."[6]

The sixth member, [James Iredell](/wiki/James_Iredell "James Iredell"), was
not confirmed until May 12, 1790. Because the full Court had only six members,
every decision that it made by a majority was also made by two-thirds (voting
four to two).[7] However, Congress has always allowed less than the Court's
full membership to make decisions, starting with a [quorum](/wiki/Quorum
"Quorum") of four justices in 1789.[8]

### Earliest beginnings to
Marshall[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Earliest beginnings to Marshall")]

Main articles: [Jay Court](/wiki/Jay_Court "Jay Court"), [Rutledge
Court](/wiki/Rutledge_Court "Rutledge Court"), [Ellsworth
Court](/wiki/Ellsworth_Court "Ellsworth Court"), and [Marshall
Court](/wiki/Marshall_Court "Marshall Court")

Under Chief Justices [Jay](/wiki/John_Jay "John Jay"),
[Rutledge](/wiki/John_Rutledge "John Rutledge"), and
[Ellsworth](/wiki/Oliver_Ellsworth "Oliver Ellsworth") (1789–1801), the Court
heard few cases; its first decision was _[West v. Barnes](/wiki/West_v._Barnes
"West v. Barnes")_ (1791), a case involving a procedural issue.[9] The Court
lacked a home of its own and had little prestige,[10] a situation not helped
by the highest-profile case of the era, _[Chisholm v.
Georgia](/wiki/Chisholm_v._Georgia "Chisholm v. Georgia")_ (1793), which was
reversed within two years by the adoption of the [Eleventh
Amendment](/wiki/Eleventh_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Eleventh Amendment to the United States Constitution").[11]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Chief_Justice_John_Marshall.jpeg/200px-
Chief_Justice_John_Marshall.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Chief_Justice_John_Marshall.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Chief_Justice_John_Marshall.jpeg "Enlarge")

Chief Justice Marshall

The Court's power and prestige grew substantially during the
[Marshall](/wiki/John_Marshall "John Marshall") Court (1801–35).[12] Under
Marshall, the Court established the power of [judicial
review](/wiki/Judicial_review_in_the_United_States "Judicial review in the
United States") over acts of Congress,[13] including specifying itself as the
supreme expositor of the [Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution
"United States Constitution") (_[Marbury v. Madison](/wiki/Marbury_v._Madison
"Marbury v. Madison")_)[14][15] and made several important constitutional
rulings giving shape and substance to the [balance of
power](/wiki/Balance_of_power_\(federalism\) "Balance of power
\(federalism\)") between the federal government and the states (prominently,
_[Martin v. Hunter's Lessee](/wiki/Martin_v._Hunter%27s_Lessee "Martin v.
Hunter's Lessee")_, _[McCulloch v. Maryland](/wiki/McCulloch_v._Maryland
"McCulloch v. Maryland")_ and _[Gibbons v. Ogden](/wiki/Gibbons_v._Ogden
"Gibbons v. Ogden")_).[16][17][18][19]

The Marshall Court also ended the practice of each justice issuing his opinion
_[seriatim](/wiki/Seriatim "Seriatim")_ ,[20] a remnant of British
tradition,[21] and instead issuing a single majority opinion.[20] Also during
Marshall's tenure, although beyond the Court's control, the impeachment and
acquittal of Justice [Samuel Chase](/wiki/Samuel_Chase "Samuel Chase") in
1804–05 helped cement the principle of [judicial
independence](/wiki/Judicial_independence "Judicial independence").[22][23]

### From Taney to
Taft[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: From Taney to Taft")]

Main articles: [Taney Court](/wiki/Taney_Court "Taney Court"), [Chase
Court](/wiki/Chase_Court "Chase Court"), [Waite Court](/wiki/Waite_Court
"Waite Court"), [Fuller Court](/wiki/Fuller_Court "Fuller Court"), [White
Court](/wiki/White_Court_\(judges\) "White Court \(judges\)"), and [Taft
Court](/wiki/Taft_Court "Taft Court")

The [Taney](/wiki/Roger_B._Taney "Roger B. Taney") Court (1836–64) made
several important rulings, such as _[Sheldon v. Sill](/wiki/Sheldon_v._Sill
"Sheldon v. Sill")_ , which held that while Congress may not limit the
subjects the Supreme Court may hear, it may limit the jurisdiction of the
lower federal courts to prevent _them_ from hearing cases dealing with certain
subjects.[24] Nevertheless, it is primarily remembered for its ruling in
_[Dred Scott v. Sandford](/wiki/Dred_Scott_v._Sandford "Dred Scott v.
Sandford")_ ,[25] which helped precipitate the [Civil
War](/wiki/United_States_Civil_War "United States Civil War").[26] In the
[Reconstruction era](/wiki/Reconstruction_era_of_the_United_States
"Reconstruction era of the United States"), the [Chase](/wiki/Salmon_P._Chase
"Salmon P. Chase"), [Waite](/wiki/Morrison_Waite "Morrison Waite"), and
[Fuller](/wiki/Melville_Fuller "Melville Fuller") Courts (1864–1910)
interpreted the new Civil War amendments to the Constitution[19] and developed
the doctrine of [substantive due process](/wiki/Substantive_due_process
"Substantive due process") (_[Lochner v. New York](/wiki/Lochner_v._New_York
"Lochner v. New York")_ ;[27] _[Adair v. United
States](/wiki/Adair_v._United_States "Adair v. United States")_).[28]

Under the [White](/wiki/Edward_Douglass_White "Edward Douglass White") and
[Taft](/wiki/William_Howard_Taft "William Howard Taft") Courts (1910–30), the
Court held that the [Fourteenth
Amendment](/wiki/Fourteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") had
[incorporated](/wiki/Incorporation_\(Bill_of_Rights\) "Incorporation \(Bill of
Rights\)") some guarantees of the [Bill of
Rights](/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights "United States Bill of Rights")
against the states (_[Gitlow v. New York](/wiki/Gitlow_v._New_York "Gitlow v.
New York")_),[29] grappled with the new [antitrust](/wiki/Antitrust
"Antitrust") statutes (_[Standard Oil Co. of New Jersey v. United
States](/wiki/Standard_Oil_Co._of_New_Jersey_v._United_States "Standard Oil
Co. of New Jersey v. United States")_), upheld the constitutionality of
[military conscription](/wiki/Conscription_in_the_United_States "Conscription
in the United States") (_[Selective Draft Law
Cases](/wiki/Selective_Draft_Law_Cases "Selective Draft Law Cases")_)[30] and
brought the substantive due process doctrine to its first apogee (_[Adkins v.
Children's Hospital](/wiki/Adkins_v._Children%27s_Hospital "Adkins v.
Children's Hospital")_).[31]

### The New Deal
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: The New Deal era")]

Main articles: [Hughes Court](/wiki/Hughes_Court "Hughes Court"), [Stone
Court](/wiki/Stone_Court_\(judges\) "Stone Court \(judges\)"), and [Vinson
Court](/wiki/Vinson_Court "Vinson Court")

During the [Hughes](/wiki/Charles_Evans_Hughes "Charles Evans Hughes"),
[Stone](/wiki/Harlan_Fiske_Stone "Harlan Fiske Stone"), and
[Vinson](/wiki/Fred_M._Vinson "Fred M. Vinson") Courts (1930–53), the Court
gained [its own accommodation](/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court_building
"United States Supreme Court building") in 1935[32] and [changed its
interpretation of the Constitution](/wiki/The_switch_in_time_that_saved_nine
"The switch in time that saved nine"), giving a broader reading to the powers
of the federal government to facilitate President [Franklin
Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_Roosevelt "Franklin Roosevelt")'s [New
Deal](/wiki/New_Deal "New Deal") (most prominently _[West Coast Hotel Co. v.
Parrish](/wiki/West_Coast_Hotel_Co._v._Parrish "West Coast Hotel Co. v.
Parrish"), [Wickard v. Filburn](/wiki/Wickard_v._Filburn "Wickard v.
Filburn")_, _[United States v. Darby](/wiki/United_States_v._Darby "United
States v. Darby")_ and _[United States v.
Butler](/wiki/United_States_v._Butler "United States v.
Butler")_).[33][34][35] During [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War
II"), the Court continued to favor government power, upholding the internment
of Japanese citizens (_[Korematsu v. United
States](/wiki/Korematsu_v._United_States "Korematsu v. United States")_) and
the mandatory pledge of allegiance (_[Minersville School District v.
Gobitis](/wiki/Minersville_School_District_v._Gobitis "Minersville School
District v. Gobitis")_). Nevertheless, _Gobitis_ was soon repudiated (_[West
Virginia State Board of Education v.
Barnette](/wiki/West_Virginia_State_Board_of_Education_v._Barnette "West
Virginia State Board of Education v. Barnette")_), and the _[Steel Seizure
Case](/wiki/Youngstown_Sheet_%26_Tube_Co._v._Sawyer "Youngstown Sheet & Tube
Co. v. Sawyer")_ restricted the pro-government trend.

### Warren and
Burger[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Warren and Burger")]

Main articles: [Warren Court](/wiki/Warren_Court "Warren Court") and [Burger
Court](/wiki/Burger_Court "Burger Court")

The [Warren](/wiki/Earl_Warren "Earl Warren") Court (1953–69) dramatically
expanded the force of Constitutional [civil liberties](/wiki/Civil_liberties
"Civil liberties").[36] It held that [segregation in public
schools](/wiki/Desegregation "Desegregation") violates [equal
protection](/wiki/Equal_protection_clause "Equal protection clause") (_[Brown
v. Board of Education](/wiki/Brown_v._Board_of_Education "Brown v. Board of
Education")_ , _[Bolling v. Sharpe](/wiki/Bolling_v._Sharpe "Bolling v.
Sharpe")_ and _[Green v. County School
Bd.](/wiki/Green_v._County_School_Board_of_New_Kent_County "Green v. County
School Board of New Kent County")_)[37] and that traditional legislative
district boundaries violated the right to vote (_[Reynolds v.
Sims](/wiki/Reynolds_v._Sims "Reynolds v. Sims")_). It created a general right
to privacy (_[Griswold v. Connecticut](/wiki/Griswold_v._Connecticut "Griswold
v. Connecticut")_),[38] limited the role of religion in public school (most
prominently _[Engel v. Vitale](/wiki/Engel_v._Vitale "Engel v. Vitale")_ and
_[Abington School District v.
Schempp](/wiki/Abington_School_District_v._Schempp "Abington School District
v. Schempp")_),[39][40]
[incorporated](/wiki/Incorporation_of_the_Bill_of_Rights "Incorporation of the
Bill of Rights") most guarantees of the [Bill of
Rights](/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights "United States Bill of Rights")
against the States—prominently _[Mapp v. Ohio](/wiki/Mapp_v._Ohio "Mapp v.
Ohio")_ (the [exclusionary rule](/wiki/Exclusionary_rule "Exclusionary rule"))
and _[Gideon v. Wainwright](/wiki/Gideon_v._Wainwright "Gideon v.
Wainwright")_ ([right to appointed counsel](/wiki/Public_defender "Public
defender")),[41][42]—and required that criminal suspects be apprised of all
these rights by police (_[Miranda v. Arizona](/wiki/Miranda_v._Arizona
"Miranda v. Arizona")_);[43] At the same time, however, the Court limited
[defamation](/wiki/Defamation "Defamation") suits by public figures (_[New
York Times v. Sullivan](/wiki/New_York_Times_v._Sullivan "New York Times v.
Sullivan")_) and supplied the government with an unbroken run of antitrust
victories.[44]

The [Burger](/wiki/Warren_E._Burger "Warren E. Burger") Court (1969–86) marked
a conservative shift.[45] It also expanded _Griswold '_s right to privacy to
strike down abortion laws (_[Roe v. Wade](/wiki/Roe_v._Wade "Roe v.
Wade")_),[46] but divided deeply on [affirmative
action](/wiki/Affirmative_action "Affirmative action") (_[Regents of the
University of California v.
Bakke](/wiki/Regents_of_the_University_of_California_v._Bakke "Regents of the
University of California v. Bakke")_)[47] and campaign finance regulation
(_[Buckley v. Valeo](/wiki/Buckley_v._Valeo "Buckley v. Valeo")_),[48] and
dithered on the [death penalty](/wiki/Death_penalty_in_the_United_States
"Death penalty in the United States"), ruling first that most applications
were defective (_[Furman v. Georgia](/wiki/Furman_v._Georgia "Furman v.
Georgia")_),[49] then that the death penalty itself was _not_ unconstitutional
(_[Gregg v. Georgia](/wiki/Gregg_v._Georgia "Gregg v. Georgia")_).[49][50][51]

### Rehnquist and
Roberts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Rehnquist and Roberts")]

Main articles: [Rehnquist Court](/wiki/Rehnquist_Court "Rehnquist Court") and
[Roberts Court](/wiki/Roberts_Court "Roberts Court")

The [Rehnquist](/wiki/William_Rehnquist "William Rehnquist") Court (1986–2005)
was noted for its revival of judicial enforcement of
[federalism](/wiki/Federalism "Federalism"),[52] emphasizing the limits of the
Constitution's affirmative grants of power (_[United States v.
Lopez](/wiki/United_States_v._Lopez "United States v. Lopez")_) and the force
of its restrictions on those powers (_[Seminole Tribe v.
Florida](/wiki/Seminole_Tribe_v._Florida "Seminole Tribe v. Florida")_ ,
_[City of Boerne v. Flores](/wiki/City_of_Boerne_v._Flores "City of Boerne v.
Flores")_).[53][54][55][56][57] It struck down single-sex state schools as a
violation of equal protection (_[United States v.
Virginia](/wiki/United_States_v._Virginia "United States v. Virginia")_), laws
against [sodomy](/wiki/Sodomy "Sodomy") as violations of [substantive due
process](/wiki/Substantive_due_process "Substantive due process") (_[Lawrence
v. Texas](/wiki/Lawrence_v._Texas "Lawrence v. Texas")_),[58] and the [line
item veto](/wiki/Line_item_veto "Line item veto") (_[Clinton v. New
York](/wiki/Clinton_v._New_York "Clinton v. New York")_), but upheld [school
vouchers](/wiki/School_vouchers "School vouchers") (_[Zelman v. Simmons-
Harris](/wiki/Zelman_v._Simmons-Harris "Zelman v. Simmons-Harris")_) and
reaffirmed _Roe '_s restrictions on abortion laws (_[Planned Parenthood v.
Casey](/wiki/Planned_Parenthood_v._Casey "Planned Parenthood v. Casey")_).[59]
The Court's decision in _[Bush v. Gore](/wiki/Bush_v._Gore "Bush v. Gore")_ ,
which ended the electoral recount during the [presidential election of
2000](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2000 "United States
presidential election, 2000"), was especially controversial.[60][61]

The [Roberts](/wiki/John_G._Roberts "John G. Roberts") Court (2005–present) is
regarded by some as more conservative than the Rehnquist Court.[62][63] Some
of its major rulings have concerned [federal
preemption](/wiki/Federal_preemption "Federal preemption") (_[Wyeth v.
Levine](/wiki/Wyeth_v._Levine "Wyeth v. Levine")_), civil procedure
(_[Twombly](/wiki/Bell_Atlantic_Corp._v._Twombly "Bell Atlantic Corp. v.
Twombly")-[Iqbal](/wiki/Ashcroft_v._Iqbal "Ashcroft v. Iqbal")_),
[abortion](/wiki/Abortion "Abortion") (_[Gonzales v.
Carhart](/wiki/Gonzales_v._Carhart "Gonzales v. Carhart")_),[64] [climate
change](/wiki/Climate_change "Climate change") (_[Massachusetts v.
EPA](/wiki/Massachusetts_v._Environmental_Protection_Agency "Massachusetts v.
Environmental Protection Agency")_), [same-sex marriage](/wiki/Same-
sex_marriage_in_the_United_States "Same-sex marriage in the United States")
(_[United States v. Windsor](/wiki/United_States_v._Windsor "United States v.
Windsor")_ and _[Obergefell v. Hodges](/wiki/Obergefell_v._Hodges "Obergefell
v. Hodges")_) and the Bill of Rights, notably in _[Citizens United v. Federal
Election Commission](/wiki/Citizens_United_v._Federal_Election_Commission
"Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission")_ ([First
Amendment](/wiki/First_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "First
Amendment to the United States Constitution")),[65]
_[Heller](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_v._Heller "District of Columbia v.
Heller")-[McDonald](/wiki/McDonald_v._Chicago "McDonald v. Chicago")_ ([Second
Amendment](/wiki/Second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Second
Amendment to the United States Constitution"))[66] and _[Baze v.
Rees](/wiki/Baze_v._Rees "Baze v. Rees")_ ([Eighth
Amendment](/wiki/Eighth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Eighth
Amendment to the United States Constitution")).[67][68]

##
Composition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Composition")]

### Size of the
Court[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Size of the Court")]

Article III of the [United States
Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States Constitution")
does not specify the number of justices. The [Judiciary Act of
1789](/wiki/Judiciary_Act_of_1789 "Judiciary Act of 1789") called for the
appointment of six "judges". Although an [1801 act](/wiki/Midnight_Judges_Act
"Midnight Judges Act") would have reduced the size of the court to five
members upon its next vacancy, an [1802 act](/wiki/Judiciary_Act_of_1802
"Judiciary Act of 1802") promptly negated the 1801 act, legally restoring the
court's size to six members before any such vacancy occurred. As the nation's
boundaries grew, Congress added justices to correspond with the growing number
of judicial circuits: [seven in 1807](/wiki/Seventh_Circuit_Act_of_1807
"Seventh Circuit Act of 1807"), [nine in
1837](/wiki/Eighth_and_Ninth_Circuits_Act_of_1837 "Eighth and Ninth Circuits
Act of 1837"), and [ten in 1863](/wiki/Tenth_Circuit_Act_of_1863 "Tenth
Circuit Act of 1863").[69]

In 1866, at the behest of Chief Justice [Chase](/wiki/Salmon_P._Chase "Salmon
P. Chase"), Congress passed [an act](/wiki/Judicial_Circuits_Act "Judicial
Circuits Act") providing that the next three justices to retire would not be
replaced, which would thin the bench to seven justices by attrition.
Consequently, one seat was removed in 1866 and a second in 1867. In 1869,
however, the [Circuit Judges Act](/wiki/Judiciary_Act_of_1869 "Judiciary Act
of 1869") returned the number of justices to nine,[70] where it has since
remained.

President [Franklin D. Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D.
Roosevelt") attempted to expand the Court in 1937. His proposal envisioned
appointment of one additional justice for each incumbent justice who reached
the age of 70 years 6 months and refused retirement, up to a maximum bench of
15 justices. The proposal was ostensibly to ease the burden of the docket on
elderly judges, but the actual purpose was widely understood as an effort to
"pack" the Court with justices who would support Roosevelt's [New
Deal](/wiki/New_Deal "New Deal").[71] The plan, usually called the "[court-
packing plan](/wiki/Judicial_Procedures_Reform_Bill_of_1937 "Judicial
Procedures Reform Bill of 1937")", failed in Congress.[72] Nevertheless, the
Court's balance began to shift within months when Justice [van
Devanter](/wiki/Willis_Van_Devanter "Willis Van Devanter") retired and was
replaced by Senator [Hugo Black](/wiki/Hugo_Black "Hugo Black"). By the end of
1941, Roosevelt had appointed seven justices and elevated [Harlan Fiske
Stone](/wiki/Harlan_Fiske_Stone "Harlan Fiske Stone") to Chief Justice.[73]

### Appointment and
confirmation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Appointment and confirmation")]

Main article: [Appointment and confirmation to the Supreme Court of the United
States](/wiki/Appointment_and_confirmation_to_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States
"Appointment and confirmation to the Supreme Court of the United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States_-
_Roberts_Court_2017.jpg/300px-Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States_-
_Roberts_Court_2017.jpg)](/wiki/File:Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States_-
_Roberts_Court_2017.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States_-_Roberts_Court_2017.jpg
"Enlarge")

The Roberts Court (April 2017 – present). Front row (left to right): [Ruth
Bader Ginsburg](/wiki/Ruth_Bader_Ginsburg "Ruth Bader Ginsburg"), [Anthony
Kennedy](/wiki/Anthony_Kennedy "Anthony Kennedy"), [John
Roberts](/wiki/John_Roberts "John Roberts") (Chief Justice), [Clarence
Thomas](/wiki/Clarence_Thomas "Clarence Thomas"), and [Stephen
Breyer](/wiki/Stephen_Breyer "Stephen Breyer"). Back row (left to right):
[Elena Kagan](/wiki/Elena_Kagan "Elena Kagan"), [Samuel A.
Alito](/wiki/Samuel_A._Alito "Samuel A. Alito"), [Sonia
Sotomayor](/wiki/Sonia_Sotomayor "Sonia Sotomayor"), and [Neil
Gorsuch](/wiki/Neil_Gorsuch "Neil Gorsuch").

The U.S. Constitution states that the President "shall nominate, and by and
with the Advice and Consent of the [Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United
States Senate"), shall appoint Judges of the Supreme Court."[74] Most
presidents nominate candidates who broadly share their ideological views,
although a justice's decisions may end up being contrary to a president's
expectations. Because the Constitution sets no qualifications for service as a
justice, a president may nominate anyone to serve, subject to Senate
confirmation.

In modern times, the confirmation process has attracted considerable attention
from the press and advocacy groups, which [lobby](/wiki/Lobbying "Lobbying")
senators to confirm or to reject a nominee depending on whether their track
record aligns with the group's views. The [Senate Judiciary
Committee](/wiki/United_States_Senate_Committee_on_the_Judiciary "United
States Senate Committee on the Judiciary") conducts hearings and votes on
whether the nomination should go to the full Senate with a positive, negative
or neutral report. The committee's practice of personally interviewing
nominees is relatively recent. The first nominee to appear before the
committee was [Harlan Fiske Stone](/wiki/Harlan_Fiske_Stone "Harlan Fiske
Stone") in 1925, who sought to quell concerns about his links to [Wall
Street](/wiki/Wall_Street "Wall Street"), and the modern practice of
questioning began with [John Marshall Harlan II](/wiki/John_Marshall_Harlan_II
"John Marshall Harlan II") in 1955.[75] Once the committee reports out the
nomination, the full Senate considers it. Rejections are relatively uncommon;
the Senate has explicitly rejected
[twelve](/wiki/List_of_failed_nominations_to_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States
"List of failed nominations to the Supreme Court of the United States")
Supreme Court nominees, most recently [Robert Bork](/wiki/Robert_Bork "Robert
Bork"), nominated by President Ronald Reagan in 1987.

Although Senate rules do not necessarily allow a negative vote in committee to
block a nomination, prior to 2017 a nomination could be blocked by
[filibuster](/wiki/Filibuster "Filibuster") once debate had begun in the full
Senate. President [Lyndon Johnson](/wiki/Lyndon_Johnson "Lyndon Johnson")'s
nomination of sitting Associate Justice [Abe Fortas](/wiki/Abe_Fortas "Abe
Fortas") to succeed [Earl Warren](/wiki/Earl_Warren "Earl Warren") as Chief
Justice in 1968 was the first successful filibuster of a Supreme Court
nominee. It included both Republican and Democratic senators concerned with
Fortas's ethics. President [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump")'s
nomination of [Neil Gorsuch](/wiki/Neil_Gorsuch "Neil Gorsuch") to the seat
vacated by Antonin Scalia was the second. Unlike the Fortas filibuster,
however, only Democratic Senators voted against
[cloture](/wiki/Cloture#United_States "Cloture") on the Gorsuch nomination,
citing his perceived conservative judicial philosophy, and the Republican
majority's prior refusal to take up President [Barack
Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama")'s [nomination of Merrick
Garland](/wiki/Merrick_Garland_Supreme_Court_nomination "Merrick Garland
Supreme Court nomination") to fill the vacancy.[76][77][78] This led the
Republican majority to change the rules and eliminate the filibuster for
Supreme Court nominations.[79]

Not every Supreme Court nominee has received a floor vote in the Senate. A
president may withdraw a nomination before an actual confirmation vote occurs,
typically because it is clear that the Senate will reject the nominee; this
occurred most recently with the nomination of [Harriet
Miers](/wiki/Harriet_Miers "Harriet Miers") in 2006. The Senate may also fail
to act on a nomination, which expires at the end of the session. For example,
President [Dwight Eisenhower](/wiki/Dwight_Eisenhower "Dwight Eisenhower")'s
first nomination of [John Marshall Harlan II](/wiki/John_Marshall_Harlan_II
"John Marshall Harlan II") in November, 1954 was not acted on by the Senate;
Eisenhower re-nominated Harlan in January 1955, and Harlan was confirmed two
months later. Most recently, as previously noted, the Senate failed to act on
the March 2016 nomination of [Merrick Garland](/wiki/Merrick_Garland "Merrick
Garland"); the nomination expired in January 2017, and the vacancy was later
filled by President [Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump")'s appointment
of [Neil Gorsuch](/wiki/Neil_Gorsuch "Neil Gorsuch").[80]

Once the Senate confirms a nomination, the president must prepare and sign a
commission, to which the Seal of the [Department of
Justice](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice "United States Department
of Justice") must be affixed, before the new justice can take office.[81] The
seniority of an associate justice is based on the commissioning date, not the
confirmation or swearing-in date.[82]

Before 1981, the approval process of justices was usually rapid. From the
[Truman](/wiki/Harry_Truman "Harry Truman") through
[Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon") administrations, justices were
typically approved within one month. From the Reagan administration to the
present, however, the process has taken much longer. Some believe this is
because Congress sees justices as playing a more political role than in the
past.[83] According to the [Congressional Research
Service](/wiki/Congressional_Research_Service "Congressional Research
Service"), the average number of days from nomination to final Senate vote
since 1975 is 67 days (2.2 months), while the median is 71 days (or 2.3
months).[84][85]

#### Recess
appointments[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Recess appointments")]

When the Senate is in recess, a president may make temporary appointments to
fill vacancies. [Recess appointees](/wiki/Recess_appointment "Recess
appointment") hold office only until the end of the next Senate session (less
than two years). The Senate must confirm the nominee for them to continue
serving; of the two chief justices and eleven associate justices who have
received recess appointments, only Chief Justice [John
Rutledge](/wiki/John_Rutledge "John Rutledge") was not subsequently
confirmed.[86]

No president since [Dwight D. Eisenhower](/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower "Dwight
D. Eisenhower") has made a recess appointment to the Court, and the practice
has become rare and controversial even in lower federal courts.[87] In 1960,
after Eisenhower had made three such appointments, the Senate passed a "sense
of the Senate" resolution that recess appointments to the Court should only be
made in "unusual circumstances."[88] Such resolutions are not legally binding
but are an expression of Congress's views in the hope of guiding executive
action.[88][89]

The 2014 Supreme Court ruling in [National Labor Relations Board v. Noel
Canning](/wiki/National_Labor_Relations_Board_v._Noel_Canning "National Labor
Relations Board v. Noel Canning") limited the ability of the President to make
recess appointments (including appointments to the Supreme Court), ruling that
the Senate decides when the Senate is in session (or in recess). Justice
[Breyer](/wiki/Stephen_Breyer "Stephen Breyer") writing for the Court, stated,
"We hold that, for purposes of the Recess Appointments Clause, the Senate is
in session when it says it is, provided that, under its own rules, it retains
the capacity to transact Senate business."[90] This ruling allows the Senate
to prevent recess appointments through the use of [pro-forma
sessions](/wiki/Pro_forma#United_States "Pro forma").[91]

###
Tenure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Tenure")]

The Constitution provides that justices "shall hold their offices during good
behavior" (unless appointed during a Senate recess). The term "good behavior"
is understood to mean justices may serve for the remainder of their lives,
unless they are [impeached and convicted](/wiki/Impeachment "Impeachment") by
Congress, [resign](/wiki/Resignation "Resignation"), or
[retire](/wiki/Retirement "Retirement").[92] Only one justice has been
impeached by the House of Representatives ([Samuel Chase](/wiki/Samuel_Chase
"Samuel Chase"), March 1804), but he was acquitted in the Senate (March
1805).[93] Moves to impeach sitting justices have occurred more recently (for
example, [William O. Douglas](/wiki/William_O._Douglas "William O. Douglas")
was the subject of hearings twice, in 1953 and again in 1970; and [Abe
Fortas](/wiki/Abe_Fortas "Abe Fortas") resigned while hearings were being
organized in 1969), but they did not reach a vote in the House. No mechanism
exists for removing a justice who is permanently incapacitated by illness or
injury, but unable (or unwilling) to resign.[94]

Because justices have indefinite tenure, timing of vacancies can be
unpredictable. Sometimes vacancies arise in quick succession, as in the early
1970s when [Lewis Franklin Powell, Jr.](/wiki/Lewis_Franklin_Powell,_Jr.
"Lewis Franklin Powell, Jr.") and William Rehnquist were nominated to replace
[Hugo Black](/wiki/Hugo_Black "Hugo Black") and [John Marshall Harlan
II](/wiki/John_Marshall_Harlan_II "John Marshall Harlan II"), who retired
within a week of each other. Sometimes a great length of time passes between
nominations, such as the eleven years between [Stephen
Breyer](/wiki/Stephen_Breyer "Stephen Breyer")'s nomination in 1994 to succeed
[Harry Blackmun](/wiki/Harry_Blackmun "Harry Blackmun") and the nomination of
[John Roberts](/wiki/John_Roberts "John Roberts") in 2005 to fill the seat of
[Sandra Day O'Connor](/wiki/Sandra_Day_O%27Connor "Sandra Day O'Connor")
(though Roberts' nomination was withdrawn and resubmitted for the role of
Chief Justice after Rehnquist died).

Despite the variability, all but four presidents have been able to appoint at
least one justice. [William Henry Harrison](/wiki/William_Henry_Harrison
"William Henry Harrison") died a month after taking office, though his
successor ([John Tyler](/wiki/John_Tyler "John Tyler")) made an appointment
during that presidential term. Likewise, [Zachary Taylor](/wiki/Zachary_Taylor
"Zachary Taylor") died 16 months after taking office, but his successor
([Millard Fillmore](/wiki/Millard_Fillmore "Millard Fillmore")) also made a
Supreme Court nomination before the end of that term. [Andrew
Johnson](/wiki/Andrew_Johnson "Andrew Johnson"), who became president after
the [assassination of Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Assassination_of_Abraham_Lincoln
"Assassination of Abraham Lincoln"), was denied the opportunity to appoint a
justice by a reduction in the size of the Court. [Jimmy
Carter](/wiki/Jimmy_Carter "Jimmy Carter") is the only person elected
president to have left office after at least one full term without having the
opportunity to appoint a justice. Somewhat similarly, presidents [James
Monroe](/wiki/James_Monroe "James Monroe"), [Franklin D.
Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt"), and [George
W. Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush "George W. Bush") each served a full term
without an opportunity to appoint a justice, but made appointments during
their subsequent terms in office. No president who has served more than one
full term has gone without at least one opportunity to make an appointment.

Three presidents have appointed justices who together served more than a
century. [Andrew Jackson](/wiki/Andrew_Jackson "Andrew Jackson"), [Abraham
Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham Lincoln"), and [Franklin D.
Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt").[95]

### Court
demographics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Court demographics")]

Main article: [Demographics of the Supreme Court of the United
States](/wiki/Demographics_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States
"Demographics of the Supreme Court of the United States")

The Court currently has six male and three female justices. Among the nine
justices, there is one African-American (Justice Thomas) and one Hispanic
(Justice Sotomayor). Two of the justices were born to at least one immigrant
parent: Justice Alito's parents were born in Italy,[96][97] and Justice
Ginsburg's father was born in Russia.[98] At least five justices are [Roman
Catholics](/wiki/Roman_Catholics "Roman Catholics") and three are
[Jewish](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism"); it is unclear whether Neil Gorsuch
considers himself a Catholic or an Episcopalian.[99] The average age is 67
years and 4 months. Every current justice has an [Ivy League](/wiki/Ivy_League
"Ivy League") background.[100] Four justices are from the state of New York,
two from California, one from New Jersey, one from Georgia, and one from
Colorado.[101] In the 19th century, every justice was a man of European
descent (usually Northern European), and almost always Protestant. Concerns
about diversity focused on geography, to represent all
[regions](/wiki/Regionalism_\(politics\) "Regionalism \(politics\)") of the
country, rather than religious, ethnic, or gender diversity.[102]

Most justices have been Protestants, including 36
[Episcopalians](/wiki/Episcopal_Church_in_the_United_States_of_America
"Episcopal Church in the United States of America"), 19
[Presbyterians](/wiki/Presbyterian "Presbyterian"), 10
[Unitarians](/wiki/Unitarianism "Unitarianism"), 5
[Methodists](/wiki/Methodist "Methodist"), and 3 [Baptists](/wiki/Baptists
"Baptists").[103][104] The first [Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholic "Roman
Catholic") justice was Roger Taney in 1836,[105] and 1916 saw the appointment
of the first Jewish justice, [Louis Brandeis](/wiki/Louis_Brandeis "Louis
Brandeis").[106] Several Catholic and Jewish justices have since been
appointed, and in recent years the situation has reversed. The Court currently
has at least five Catholic justices.[99]

Racial, ethnic, and gender diversity began to increase in the late 20th
century. [Thurgood Marshall](/wiki/Thurgood_Marshall "Thurgood Marshall")
became the first [African American](/wiki/African_American "African American")
justice in 1967.[106] [Sandra Day O'Connor](/wiki/Sandra_Day_O%27Connor
"Sandra Day O'Connor") became the first female justice in 1981.[106] Marshall
was succeeded by African-American [Clarence Thomas](/wiki/Clarence_Thomas
"Clarence Thomas") in 1991.[107] O'Connor was joined by [Ruth Bader
Ginsburg](/wiki/Ruth_Bader_Ginsburg "Ruth Bader Ginsburg") in 1993.[108] After
O'Connor's retirement Ginsburg was joined in 2009 by [Sonia
Sotomayor](/wiki/Sonia_Sotomayor "Sonia Sotomayor"), the first
[Hispanic](/wiki/Hispanic "Hispanic") and [Latina](/wiki/Latina "Latina")
justice;[106] and in 2010 by [Elena Kagan](/wiki/Elena_Kagan "Elena Kagan"),
for a total of four female justices in the Court's history.[108]

There have been six foreign-born justices in the Court's history: [James
Wilson](/wiki/James_Wilson "James Wilson") (1789–1798), born in
[Caskardy](/wiki/Ceres,_Fife "Ceres, Fife"), [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland
"Scotland"); [James Iredell](/wiki/James_Iredell "James Iredell") (1790–1799),
born in [Lewes](/wiki/Lewes "Lewes"), [England](/wiki/England "England");
[William Paterson](/wiki/William_Paterson_\(judge\) "William Paterson
\(judge\)") (1793–1806), born in [County Antrim](/wiki/County_Antrim "County
Antrim"), [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland"); [David
Brewer](/wiki/David_Josiah_Brewer "David Josiah Brewer") (1889–1910), born in
[Smyrna](/wiki/Smyrna "Smyrna"), [Turkey](/wiki/Turkey "Turkey"); [George
Sutherland](/wiki/George_Sutherland "George Sutherland") (1922–1939), born in
[Buckinghamshire](/wiki/Buckinghamshire "Buckinghamshire"), England; and
[Felix Frankfurter](/wiki/Felix_Frankfurter "Felix Frankfurter") (1939–1962),
born in [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"), [Austria](/wiki/Austria
"Austria").[106]

### Retired
justices[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Retired justices")]

There are currently three living retired justices of the Supreme Court of the
United States: [John Paul Stevens](/wiki/John_Paul_Stevens "John Paul
Stevens"), [Sandra Day O'Connor](/wiki/Sandra_Day_O%27Connor "Sandra Day
O'Connor") and [David Souter](/wiki/David_Souter "David Souter"). As retired
justices, they no longer participate in the work of the Supreme Court, but may
be designated for temporary assignments to sit on lower federal courts,
usually the [United States Courts of
Appeals](/wiki/United_States_Courts_of_Appeals "United States Courts of
Appeals"). Such assignments are formally made by the [Chief
Justice](/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_United_States "Chief Justice of the United
States"), on request of the [chief judge](/wiki/Chief_Judge "Chief Judge") of
the lower court and with the consent of the retired justice. In recent years,
Justice O'Connor has sat with several Courts of Appeals around the country,
and Justice Souter has frequently sat on the [First
Circuit](/wiki/First_Circuit "First Circuit"), the court of which he was
briefly a member before joining the Supreme Court.

The status of a retired justice is analogous to that of a circuit or district
court judge who has taken [senior status](/wiki/Senior_status "Senior
status"), and eligibility of a supreme court justice to assume retired status
(rather than simply resign from the bench) is governed by the same age and
service criteria.

In recent times, justices tend to strategically plan their decisions to leave
the bench with personal, institutional, ideological, partisan and sometimes
even political factors playing a role.[109][110] The fear of mental decline
and death often motivates justices to step down. The desire to maximize the
Court's strength and legitimacy through one retirement at a time, when the
Court is in recess, and during non-presidential election years suggests a
concern for institutional health. Finally, especially in recent decades, many
justices have timed their departure to coincide with a philosophically
compatible president holding office, to ensure that a like-minded successor
would be appointed.[111][112]

### Seniority and
seating[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Seniority and seating")]

Many of the internal operations of the Court are organized by
[seniority](/wiki/Seniority "Seniority") of justices; the chief justice is
considered the most senior member of the court, regardless of the length of
his or her service. The associate justices are then ranked by the length of
their service.

[![The interior of the United States Supreme
Court](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Inside_the_United_States_Supreme_Court.jpg/220px-
Inside_the_United_States_Supreme_Court.jpg)](/wiki/File:Inside_the_United_States_Supreme_Court.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Inside_the_United_States_Supreme_Court.jpg "Enlarge")

The interior of the United States Supreme Court

During Court sessions, the justices sit according to seniority, with the Chief
Justice in the center, and the Associate Justices on alternating sides, with
the most senior Associate Justice on the Chief Justice's immediate right, and
the most junior Associate Justice seated on the left farthest away from the
Chief Justice. Therefore, the current court sits as follows from left to
right, from the perspective of those facing the Court: Kagan, Alito, Ginsburg,
Kennedy (most senior Associate Justice), Roberts (Chief Justice), Thomas,
Breyer, Sotomayor, and Gorsuch. In the official yearly Court photograph,
justices are arranged similarly, with the five most senior members sitting in
the front row in the same order as they would sit during Court sessions (The
most recent photograph includes Ginsburg, Kennedy, Roberts, Thomas, Breyer),
and the four most junior justices standing behind them, again in the same
order as they would sit during Court sessions (Kagan, Alito, Sotomayor,
Gorsuch).

In the justices' private conferences, current practice is for them to speak
and vote in order of seniority to begin with the chief justice first and end
with the most junior associate justice. The most junior associate justice in
these conferences is charged with any menial tasks the justices may require as
they convene alone, such as answering the door of their conference room,
serving beverages and transmitting orders of the court to the clerk.[113]
Justice [Joseph Story](/wiki/Joseph_Story "Joseph Story") served the longest
as junior justice, from February 3, 1812, to September 1, 1823, for a total of
4,228 days. Justice [Stephen Breyer](/wiki/Stephen_Breyer "Stephen Breyer")
follows very closely behind serving from August 3, 1994, to January 31, 2006,
for a total of 4,199 days.[114] Justice [Elena Kagan](/wiki/Elena_Kagan "Elena
Kagan") comes in at a distant third serving from August 6, 2010, to April 10,
2017, for a total of 2439 days.

###
Salary[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Salary")]

Main article: [Federal judge salaries in the United
States](/wiki/Federal_judge_salaries_in_the_United_States "Federal judge
salaries in the United States")

As of 2017, associate justices are paid $251,800 and the chief justice
$263,300.[115] [Article III, Section 1](/wiki/Compensation_Clause
"Compensation Clause") of the U.S. Constitution prohibits Congress from
reducing the pay for incumbent justices. Once a justice meets [age and service
requirements](/wiki/United_States_federal_judge#Retirement "United States
federal judge"), the justice may retire. Judicial pensions are based on the
same formula used for federal employees, but a justice's pension, as with
other federal courts judges, can never be less than their salary at the time
of retirement.

### Judicial
leanings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Judicial leanings")]

See also: [Ideological leanings of U.S. Supreme Court
justices](/wiki/Ideological_leanings_of_U.S._Supreme_Court_justices
"Ideological leanings of U.S. Supreme Court justices")

Although justices are nominated by the president in power, justices do not
represent or receive official endorsements from political parties, as is
accepted practice in the legislative and executive branches. Jurists are,
however, informally categorized in legal and political circles as being
judicial conservatives, moderates, or liberals. Such leanings, however,
generally refer to legal outlook rather than a political or legislative one.
The nominations of justices are endorsed by individual politicians in the
legislative branch who vote their approval or disapproval of the nominated
justice.

Following the confirmation of Neil Gorsuch in 2017, the Court consists of five
justices appointed by Republican presidents and four appointed by Democratic
presidents. It is popularly accepted that Chief Justice
[Roberts](/wiki/John_Roberts "John Roberts") and associate justices
[Thomas](/wiki/Clarence_Thomas "Clarence Thomas") and
[Alito](/wiki/Samuel_Alito "Samuel Alito") (appointed by Republican
presidents) comprise the Court's conservative wing. Justices
[Ginsburg](/wiki/Ruth_Bader_Ginsburg "Ruth Bader Ginsburg"),
[Breyer](/wiki/Stephen_Breyer "Stephen Breyer"),
[Sotomayor](/wiki/Sonia_Sotomayor "Sonia Sotomayor") and
[Kagan](/wiki/Elena_Kagan "Elena Kagan") (appointed by Democratic presidents)
comprise the Court's liberal wing. Justice [Kennedy](/wiki/Anthony_Kennedy
"Anthony Kennedy") (appointed by [President Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan
"Ronald Reagan")) is generally considered "a conservative who has occasionally
voted with liberals",[116] and up until Justice Scalia's death, he was often
the [swing vote](/wiki/Swing_vote "Swing vote") that determined the outcome of
cases divided between the conservative and liberal wings.[117][118][119]
Gorsuch had a track record as a reliably conservative judge in the 10th
circuit.[120]

[Tom Goldstein](/wiki/Tom_Goldstein "Tom Goldstein") argued in an article in
[SCOTUSblog](/wiki/SCOTUSblog "SCOTUSblog") in 2010, that the popular view of
the Supreme Court as sharply divided along ideological lines and each side
pushing an agenda at every turn is "in significant part a caricature designed
to fit certain preconceptions."[121] He pointed out that in the 2009 term,
almost half the cases were decided unanimously, and only about 20% were
decided by a 5-to-4 vote. Barely one in ten cases involved the narrow
liberal/conservative divide (fewer if the cases where Sotomayor recused
herself are not included). He also pointed to several cases that defied the
popular conception of the ideological lines of the Court.[122] Goldstein
further argued that the large number of pro-criminal-defendant [summary
dismissals](/wiki/Summary_judgment "Summary judgment") (usually cases where
the justices decide that the lower courts significantly misapplied precedent
and reverse the case without briefing or argument) were an illustration that
the conservative justices had not been aggressively ideological. Likewise,
Goldstein stated that the critique that the liberal justices are more likely
to invalidate acts of Congress, show inadequate deference to the political
process, and be disrespectful of precedent, also lacked merit: Thomas has most
often called for overruling prior precedent (even if long standing) that he
views as having been wrongly decided, and during the 2009 term Scalia and
Thomas voted most often to invalidate legislation.

According to statistics compiled by SCOTUSblog, in the twelve terms from 2000
to 2011, an average of 19 of the opinions on major issues (22%) were decided
by a 5–4 vote, with an average of 70% of those split opinions decided by a
Court divided along the traditionally perceived ideological lines (about 15%
of all opinions issued). Over that period, the conservative bloc has been in
the majority about 62% of the time that the Court has divided along
ideological lines, which represents about 44% of all the 5–4 decisions.[123]

In the October 2010 term, the Court decided 86 cases, including 75 signed
opinions and 5 summary reversals (where the Court reverses a lower court
without arguments and without issuing an opinion on the case).[124][125] Four
were decided with unsigned opinions, two cases affirmed by [an equally divided
Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States#Decision "Supreme Court of the
United States"), and two cases were dismissed as improvidently granted.
Justice Kagan [recused](/wiki/Judicial_disqualification "Judicial
disqualification") herself from 26 of the cases due to her prior role as
[United States Solicitor General](/wiki/United_States_Solicitor_General
"United States Solicitor General"). Of the 80 cases, 38 (about 48%, the
highest percentage since the October 2005 term) were decided unanimously (9–0
or 8–0), and 16 decisions were made by a 5–4 vote (about 20%, compared to 18%
in the October 2009 term, and 29% in the October 2008 term).[126] However, in
fourteen of the sixteen 5–4 decisions, the Court divided along the traditional
ideological lines (with Ginsburg, Breyer, Sotomayor, and Kagan on the liberal
side, and Roberts, Scalia, Thomas, and Alito on the conservative, and Kennedy
providing the "swing vote"). This represents 87% of those 16 cases, the
highest rate in the past 10 years. The conservative bloc, joined by Kennedy,
formed the majority in 63% of the 5–4 decisions, the highest cohesion rate of
that bloc in the Roberts court.[124][127][128][129][130]

In the October 2011 term, the Court decided 75 cases. Of these, 33 (44%) were
decided unanimously, and 15 (20%, the same percentage as in the previous term)
were decided by a vote of 5–4. Of the latter 15, the Court divided along the
perceived ideological lines 10 times with Justice Kennedy joining the
conservative justices (Roberts, Scalia, Thomas and Alito) five times and with
the liberal justices (Ginsburg, Breyer, Sotomayor and Kagan) five
times.[123][131][132]

In the October 2012 term, the Court decided 78 cases. Five of them were
decided [in unsigned opinions](/wiki/Per_curiam_decision "Per curiam
decision"). 38 out of the 78 decisions (representing 49% of the decisions)
were unanimous in judgement, with 24 decisions being completely unanimous (a
single opinion with every justice that participated joining it). This was the
largest percentage of unanimous decisions that the Court had in ten years,
since the October 2002 term (when 51% of the decisions handed down were
unanimous). The Court split 5–4 in 23 cases (29% of the total); of these, 16
broke down along the traditionally perceived ideological lines, with Chief
Justice Roberts and Justices Scalia, Thomas, and Alito on one side, Justices
Ginsburg, Breyer, Sotomayor and Kagan on the other, and Justice Kennedy
holding the balance. Of these 16 cases, Justice Kennedy sided with the
conservatives on 10 cases, and with the liberals on 6. Three cases were
decided by an interesting alignment of justices, with Chief Justice Roberts
joined by Justices Kennedy, Thomas, Breyer and Alito in the majority, with
Justices Scalia, Ginsburg, Sotomayor, and Kagan in the minority. The greatest
agreement between justices was between Ginsburg and Kagan, who agreed on 72 of
the 75 (96%) cases, in which both voted; the lowest agreement between justices
was between Ginsburg and Alito, who agreed only on 45 out of 77 (54%) cases,
in which they both participated. Justice Kennedy was in the majority of 5–4
decisions on 20 out of 24 (83%) cases, and in 71 of 78 (91%) cases during the
term, in line with his position as the "swing vote" of the Court.[133][134]

##
Facilities[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Facilities")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Panorama_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_Building_at_Dusk.jpg/220px-
Panorama_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_Building_at_Dusk.jpg)](/wiki/File:Panorama_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_Building_at_Dusk.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Panorama_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_Building_at_Dusk.jpg
"Enlarge")

[The present U.S. Supreme Court
building](/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court_building "United States Supreme
Court building") as viewed from the front

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b1/SCOTUS-
oldsenate.jpg/220px-SCOTUS-oldsenate.jpg)](/wiki/File:SCOTUS-oldsenate.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:SCOTUS-oldsenate.jpg "Enlarge")

From the 1860s until the 1930s, the court sat in the [Old Senate
Chamber](/wiki/Old_Senate_Chamber "Old Senate Chamber") of the [U.S.
Capitol](/wiki/U.S._Capitol "U.S. Capitol").

Main article: [United States Supreme Court
Building](/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court_Building "United States Supreme
Court Building")

The Supreme Court first met on February 1, 1790, at the Merchants' Exchange
Building in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"). When
Philadelphia became the capital, the Court met briefly in [Independence
Hall](/wiki/Independence_Hall "Independence Hall") before settling in [Old
City Hall](/wiki/Old_City_Hall_\(Philadelphia\) "Old City Hall
\(Philadelphia\)") from 1791 until 1800. After the government moved to
Washington, D.C., the Court occupied various spaces in the [United States
Capitol](/wiki/United_States_Capitol "United States Capitol") building until
1935, when it moved into its own purpose-built home. The four-story building
was designed by [Cass Gilbert](/wiki/Cass_Gilbert "Cass Gilbert") in a
classical style sympathetic to the surrounding buildings of the
[Capitol](/wiki/United_States_Capitol "United States Capitol") and [Library of
Congress](/wiki/Library_of_Congress "Library of Congress"), and is clad in
marble. The building includes the courtroom, justices' chambers, an extensive
[law library](/wiki/Law_library "Law library"), various meeting spaces, and
auxiliary services including a gymnasium. The Supreme Court building is within
the ambit of the [Architect of the Capitol](/wiki/Architect_of_the_Capitol
"Architect of the Capitol"), but maintains its [own police
force](/wiki/Supreme_Court_Police "Supreme Court Police") separate from the
[Capitol Police](/wiki/United_States_Capitol_Police "United States Capitol
Police").[135]

Located across First Street from the [United States
Capitol](/wiki/United_States_Capitol "United States Capitol") at One First
Street NE and Maryland Avenue,[136][137] the building is open to the public
from 9 am to 4:30 pm weekdays but closed on weekends and
[holidays](/wiki/Federal_holidays_in_the_United_States "Federal holidays in
the United States").[136] Visitors may not tour the actual courtroom
unaccompanied. There is a cafeteria, a gift shop, exhibits, and a half-hour
informational film.[135] When the Court is not in session, lectures about the
courtroom are held hourly from 9:30 am to 3:30 pm and reservations are not
necessary.[135] When the Court is in session the public may attend oral
arguments, which are held twice each morning (and sometimes afternoons) on
Mondays, Tuesdays, and Wednesdays in two-week intervals from October through
late April, with breaks during December and February. Visitors are seated on a
first-come first-served basis. One estimate is there are about 250 seats
available.[138] The number of open seats varies from case to case; for
important cases, some visitors arrive the day before and wait through the
night. From mid-May until the end of June, the court releases orders and
opinions beginning at 10 am, and these 15 to 30-minute sessions are open to
the public on a similar basis.[135] Supreme Court Police are available to
answer questions.[136]

##
Jurisdiction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Jurisdiction")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Marbury_v_Madison_John_Marshall_by_Swatjester_crop.jpg/220px-
Marbury_v_Madison_John_Marshall_by_Swatjester_crop.jpg)](/wiki/File:Marbury_v_Madison_John_Marshall_by_Swatjester_crop.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Marbury_v_Madison_John_Marshall_by_Swatjester_crop.jpg
"Enlarge")

Inscription on the wall of the Supreme Court Building from _[Marbury v.
Madison](/wiki/Marbury_v._Madison "Marbury v. Madison")_ , in which Chief
Justice John Marshall outlined the concept of judicial review

Main article: [Procedures of the Supreme Court of the United
States](/wiki/Procedures_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Procedures
of the Supreme Court of the United States")

Congress is authorized by Article III of the federal Constitution to regulate
the Supreme Court's appellate jurisdiction. The Supreme Court has
[original](/wiki/Original_jurisdiction "Original jurisdiction") and exclusive
jurisdiction over cases between two or more states,[139] but may decline to
hear such cases.[140] It also possesses original, but not exclusive,
jurisdiction to hear "all actions or proceedings to which ambassadors, other
public ministers, consuls, or vice consuls of foreign states are parties; all
controversies between the United States and a State; and all actions or
proceedings by a State against the citizens of another State or against
aliens."[141]

In 1906, the Court asserted its original jurisdiction to prosecute individuals
for [contempt of court](/wiki/Contempt_of_court "Contempt of court") in
_[United States v. Shipp](/wiki/United_States_v._Shipp "United States v.
Shipp")_.[142] The resulting proceeding remains the only contempt proceeding
and only criminal trial in the Court's history.[143][144] The contempt
proceeding arose from the [lynching of Ed
Johnson](/wiki/Lynching_of_Ed_Johnson "Lynching of Ed Johnson") in
[Chattanooga](/wiki/Chattanooga "Chattanooga"), [Tennessee](/wiki/Tennessee
"Tennessee") the evening after Justice [John Marshall
Harlan](/wiki/John_Marshall_Harlan "John Marshall Harlan") granted Johnson a
stay of execution to allow his lawyers to file an appeal. Johnson was removed
from his jail cell by a lynch mob—aided by the local sheriff who left the
prison virtually unguarded—and hung from a bridge, after which a deputy
sheriff pinned a note on Johnson's body reading: "To Justice Harlan. Come get
your nigger now."[143] The local sheriff, John Shipp, cited the Supreme
Court's intervention as the rationale for the lynching. The Court appointed
its deputy clerk as [special master](/wiki/Special_master "Special master") to
preside over the trial in Chattanooga with closing arguments made in
Washington before the Supreme Court justices, who found nine individuals
guilty of contempt, sentencing three to 90 days in jail and the rest to 60
days in jail.[143][144][145]

In all other cases, however, the Court has only appellate jurisdiction,
including the ability to issue [writs of mandamus](/wiki/Writ_of_mandamus
"Writ of mandamus") and [writs of prohibition](/wiki/Writ_of_prohibition "Writ
of prohibition") to lower courts. It considers cases based on its original
jurisdiction very rarely; almost all cases are brought to the Supreme Court on
appeal. In practice, the only original jurisdiction cases heard by the Court
are disputes between two or more states.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The Court's appellate jurisdiction consists of appeals from [federal courts of
appeal](/wiki/United_States_courts_of_appeals "United States courts of
appeals") (through [certiorari](/wiki/Certiorari "Certiorari"), [certiorari
before judgment](/wiki/Certiorari_before_judgment "Certiorari before
judgment"), and [certified
questions](/wiki/Certified_question#Certification_of_questions_to_the_United_States_Supreme_Court
"Certified question")),[146] the [United States Court of Appeals for the Armed
Forces](/wiki/United_States_Court_of_Appeals_for_the_Armed_Forces "United
States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces") (through certiorari),[147] the
[Supreme Court of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Puerto_Rico "Supreme
Court of Puerto Rico") (through certiorari),[148] the [Supreme Court of the
Virgin Islands](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_Virgin_Islands "Supreme Court of
the Virgin Islands") (through certiorari),[149] the [District of Columbia
Court of Appeals](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_Court_of_Appeals "District of
Columbia Court of Appeals") (through certiorari),[150] and "final judgments or
decrees rendered by the highest court of a State in which a decision could be
had" (through certiorari).[150] In the last case, an appeal may be made to the
Supreme Court from a lower state court if the state's highest court declined
to hear an appeal or lacks jurisdiction to hear an appeal. For example, a
decision rendered by one of the [Florida District Courts of
Appeal](/wiki/Florida_District_Courts_of_Appeal "Florida District Courts of
Appeal") can be appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court if (a) the [Supreme Court
of Florida](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Florida "Supreme Court of Florida")
declined to grant certiorari, e.g. _[Florida Star v. B. J.
F.](/wiki/Florida_Star_v._B._J._F. "Florida Star v. B. J. F.")_ , or (b) the
district court of appeal issued a [per curiam](/wiki/Per_curiam_decision "Per
curiam decision") decision simply affirming the lower court's decision without
discussing the merits of the case, since the Supreme Court of Florida lacks
jurisdiction to hear appeals of such decisions.[151] The power of the Supreme
Court to consider appeals from state courts, rather than just federal courts,
was created by the [Judiciary Act of 1789](/wiki/Judiciary_Act_of_1789
"Judiciary Act of 1789") and upheld early in the Court's history, by its
rulings in _[Martin v. Hunter's Lessee](/wiki/Martin_v._Hunter%27s_Lessee
"Martin v. Hunter's Lessee")_ (1816) and _[Cohens v.
Virginia](/wiki/Cohens_v._Virginia "Cohens v. Virginia")_ (1821). The Supreme
Court is the only federal court that has jurisdiction over direct appeals from
state court decisions, although there are several devices that permit so-
called "collateral review" of state cases. It has to be noted that this
"collateral review" often only applies to individuals on death row and not
through the regular judicial system.[152]

Since Article Three of the United States Constitution stipulates that federal
courts may only entertain "cases" or "controversies", the Supreme Court cannot
decide cases that are moot and it does not render [advisory
opinions](/wiki/Advisory_opinion "Advisory opinion"), as the supreme courts of
some states may do. For example, in _[DeFunis v.
Odegaard](/wiki/DeFunis_v._Odegaard "DeFunis v. Odegaard")_ ,
[416](/wiki/List_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_cases,_volume_416 "List of
United States Supreme Court cases, volume 416")
[U.S.](/wiki/United_States_Reports "United States Reports")
[312](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/416/312/) (1974), the Court
dismissed a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of a law school
affirmative action policy because the plaintiff student had graduated since he
began the lawsuit, and a decision from the Court on his claim would not be
able to redress any injury he had suffered. However, the Court recognizes some
circumstances where it is appropriate to hear a case that is seemingly moot.
If an issue is "capable of repetition yet evading review", the Court will
address it even though the party before the Court would not himself be made
whole by a favorable result. In _Roe v. Wade_ ,
[410](/wiki/List_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_cases,_volume_410 "List of
United States Supreme Court cases, volume 410")
[U.S.](/wiki/United_States_Reports "United States Reports")
[113](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/410/113/) (1973), and other
abortion cases, the Court addresses the merits of claims pressed by pregnant
women seeking abortions even if they are no longer pregnant because it takes
longer than the typical human gestation period to appeal a case through the
lower courts to the Supreme Court. Another mootness exception is voluntary
cessation of unlawful conduct, in which the Court considers the probability of
recurrence and plaintiff's need for relief.[153]

### Justices as Circuit
Justices[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Justices as Circuit Justices")]

The United States is divided into thirteen [circuit courts of
appeals](/wiki/United_States_court_of_appeals "United States court of
appeals"), each of which is assigned a "circuit justice" from the Supreme
Court. Although this concept has been in continuous existence throughout the
history of the republic, its meaning has changed through time.

Under the [Judiciary Act of 1789](/wiki/Judiciary_Act_of_1789 "Judiciary Act
of 1789"), each justice was required to "ride circuit", or to travel within
the assigned circuit and consider cases alongside local judges. This practice
encountered opposition from many justices, who cited the difficulty of travel.
Moreover, there was a potential for a conflict of interest on the Court if a
justice had previously decided the same case while riding circuit. Circuit
riding was abolished in 1891.

Today, the circuit justice for each circuit is responsible for dealing with
certain types of applications that, under the Court's rules, may be addressed
by a single justice. These include applications for emergency stays (including
stays of execution in death-penalty cases) and injunctions pursuant to the
[All Writs Act](/wiki/All_Writs_Act "All Writs Act") arising from cases within
that circuit, as well as routine requests such as requests for extensions of
time. In the past, circuit justices also sometimes ruled on motions for
[bail](/wiki/Bail "Bail") in criminal cases, writs of [habeas
corpus](/wiki/Habeas_corpus "Habeas corpus"), and applications for [writs of
error](/wiki/Writ_of_error "Writ of error") granting permission to appeal.
Ordinarily, a justice will resolve such an application by simply endorsing it
"granted" or "denied" or entering a standard form of order. However, the
justice may elect to write an opinion—referred to as an [in-chambers
opinion](/wiki/In-chambers_opinion "In-chambers opinion")—in such matters if
he or she wishes.

A circuit justice may sit as a judge on the [Court of
Appeals](/wiki/Court_of_Appeals "Court of Appeals") of that circuit, but over
the past hundred years, this has rarely occurred. A circuit justice sitting
with the Court of Appeals has seniority over the chief judge of the circuit.

The chief justice has traditionally been assigned to the District of Columbia
Circuit, the Fourth Circuit (which includes Maryland and Virginia, the states
surrounding the District of Columbia), and since it was established, the
[Federal Circuit](/wiki/Federal_Circuit "Federal Circuit"). Each associate
justice is assigned to one or two judicial circuits.

As of June 27, 2017, the allotment of the justices among the circuits is:[154]
